entry.title: Re: HTML Controls Misbehaving in SAP ‚Äì SE80 and Workflow...
entry.content:
@RicardoRomero_1 

Hi Ricardo,

it's not Adobe-related but an issue introduced by a recent Windows update for Webview2 Version 144.xxx which causea the HTML control in SAP to no longer work properly in many places in SAP.

SAP has released a KBA which gets updated when there's any news about a fix:
3704912 - Latest Webview2 Version 144.xxx causes problems with SAP GUI HTML control when using edge as browser control in SAP GUI for Windows

A quick fix is to change the interactive design in the GUI-setting (version 800 is affected) to "Internet Explorer" for the time being. This may however cause other issues elsewhere because IE is no longer really supported.

Hope this helps!

Cheers

B√§rbel

entry.title: Re: Need BAdI for Auto-Setting Validity Date in Sales Enq...
entry.content:
Hello @Guna_M 

What you have described is good for sales functional object but for public cloud you need to consider a different approach. The public cloud does not permit the implementation of enhancements through SE18 or 19. Public cloud offers the use of Custom Logic with the released cloud BAdIs and configuration features that exist specifically for validity date proposal. You can implement both requirements limit the impact to your sales inquiries.

For the Auto set Validity Date to Enquiry Date plus 30 days, the best practice is to use flexible proposal of validity dates. This is standard configuration for proposing the valid to date for sales inquiries and quotations, based on calendar and offset rules. See Flexible Proposal of Validity Dates for more details.

Doing that will help you avoid changing a standard field through a BAdI, which is generally not supported for many standard fields in public cloud. See KBA 2733433

The following Blog: S/4HANA Q2C Sales Flexibility ‚Äì Determine Valid-to Date on Sales Inquiry and Sales Quotation via CPF also provides some insights.

In your CBC, search for Flexible Proposal of Validity Dates, create a rule for sales inquiry and restrict it to document type IN. Then set the offset rule to propose valid To = Enquiry Date plus 30 days, save and publish.

For you to Freeze Item Quantity after Validity Date has expire, you cannot make only one standard field read only while keeping others editable using classic GUI exits. However, you can block saving when a user tries to change quantity after the validity date. That is the usual public cloud pattern. You may consider using SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE to validate the document and stop saving with an error message. In the BAdI logic check SalesDocumentType is equls to IN, only then run the validity check but do not run it for quotations or orders. See Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) for Sales Documents and KBA 3509178 for more details.

Here is a step guidance:

In the Custom Logic app,

create a new implementation for SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE, add a filter condition for Sales Document Type = IN

You can implement logic as you need e.g.,

If today is greater than Valid To date, if quantity was changed, raise an error message and prevent save.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: RAP Draft Action EDIT Contract Violation: Failed not allowed cl_dsp_act_comn_exec_add_impl - Solved
entry.content:
Scenarion:  Custom RAP unmanaged behavior implementation with draft  - strict 

 draft action Edit with additional implementation; // additional implementation to provide virtual elements

In this Implementation of EDIT in the Z-behavior pool we checked if a delivery on this items exists, if so we raise a FAILED an a REPOTED Message 

Due to changes in the RAP Framework it looks like in the method EDIT with additional behavior, no FAILED is allowed anymore ( See comment below )
The HTTP-Error is the result of a dump:  ‚ÄúContract Violation: Failed not allowed‚Äù

The issue is a change in the RAP framework that is not compatible with our current implementation  Edit (with additional implementation).   During the EDIT operation, an error is detected because the tour has deliveries and the fields FAILED and REPORTED are filled.
However, RAP no longer allows this.

Cass cl_dsp_act_comn_exec_add_impl -> lcl_implementation -> Method lif_implementation~execute  are these new lines

 

These lines raise the short dump if there are failed messages: 

Solution

Business Requirement is to do checks right before an entity will be put into edit mode, such that an draft for an active item is created.  Using the provided RAP Feature Control is not an option, as:
1. We do not want to check that upfront for all items of the list 
2. We wand to do the check in that moment a user requests the draft.

We moved the check into the framework method LOCK, here we are allowed to raise FAILED an Reported. 

I am not 100% sure that this is the best place for "Draft Pre-Checks" but I did not find any better. 
Pre-Checks are not possible for EDIT actions. 


Thanks go out to @Sschlegel &  Bj√∂rn Schulz

entry.title: SAP instance fails to start when SNC (Kerberos) is enabled
entry.content:
Hello

 when we try to start SAP, it does not come up

 SAP instance fails to start when SNC (Kerberos) is enabled ‚Äì work processes abort during SNC initialization

System / Environment

SAP NetWeaver AS ABAP

OSS: Linux (RHEL 9)

Database: Oracle 19c

 SNC configured with Kerberos (MIT Kerberos, GSS-API)

 snc/gssapi_lib set to /usr/lib64/libgssapi_krb5.so

 snc/identity/as configured with machine principal

 

 The SAP ABAP instance fails to start when SNC is enabled.

The startup stops during work process initialization.

 When SNC parameters are disabled, the SAP system starts successfully.

 

 

 Observed Behavior

 SAP instance startup proceeds normally:

 DIspatcher starts

 Database connection succeeds

 Work processes are spawned

 During work process startup, SNC initialization begins.

 

The SNC library is successfully loaded:

 SncInit(): found snc/gssapi_lib=/usr/lib64/libgssapi_krb5.so

File "/usr/lib64/libgssapi_krb5.so" dynamically loaded as GSS-API v2 library.

 Immediately after loading the GSS-API library, the work process terminates with signal 6 (SIGABRT).

 

This behavior repeats for multiple work processes, causing the instance to fail startup

 

 SncInit(): Initializing Secure Network Communication (SNC)

SncInit(): found snc/gssapi_lib=/usr/lib64/libgssapi_krb5.so

File "/usr/lib64/libgssapi_krb5.so" dynamically loaded as GSS-API v2 library.

 

 /usr/lib64/libc.so.6(abort+0xd3)

...

/oracle/SID/19/lib/libclntsh.so.11.1(krb5int_key_register+0xb1)

/oracle/SID/19/lib/libclntsh.so.11.1(gss_krb5int_lib_init+0x29)

...

SncPDLInit()

SncInit()

ThSncInit()

ThInit()

abort()

 

 

 

System remains unavailable

 

Disabling SNC (snc/enable = 0) allows the system to start normally

 

 

 

 

Although SAP loads the configured GSS-API library successfully, the stack trace shows that Kerberos-related functions are being executed from the Oracle client library (libclntsh.so) at the time of the abort.

 

 

 QUESTIONS??

Why SAP work processes abort during SNC initialization after successfully loading the configured GSS-API library

 

How SAP expects SNC / Kerberos to behave when Oracle client libraries are present in the same process

 

Any known SAP Notes, restrictions, or supported configurations for:

 

SNC (Kerberos)

 

Oracle 19c client

 

Linux platforms

entry.title: Re: Best Practices for Structuring Business Object Migrat...
entry.content:
Dear @Halser_T,

Below is a pragmatic CALM-friendly way to structure data migration work for Public Cloud implementations. It is aligned with how SAP Cloud ALM is designed to be used SAP Activate template tasks + Requirements ->User Stories/Tasks + timeboxes/milestones + workstreams/tags

Question 1. How should migration objects be represented in SAP Cloud ALM?

Recommended modeling works well in real projects

Use a 3-layer structure:

1. Requirement (scope + quality gate)
Use Requirements to capture the what and how-good at a level that business/data owners can sign off:

    • object/domain scope (what‚Äôs in / what‚Äôs out)
    • data owners and sources
    • acceptance criteria (reconciliation rules, tolerances, completeness, audit evidence)
    • dependencies

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/defining-requirements

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/approving-requirements

2. User Story (deliverable outcome per object or object-group)
Use User Stories to represent the migration deliverable you want to manage end-to-end for example:

    • Business Partner master migrated and reconciled
    • Material master migrated and validated
    • Open AR items migrated and balanced
      User stories work well because Cloud ALM provides traceability views that roll up progress from sub-tasks/tests to show readiness

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/user-story-traceability

3. (Sub-)Tasks (execution steps)
Put the operational steps into sub-tasks under the user story or project tasks where it‚Äôs cross-cutting. SAP Cloud ALM explicitly supports tasks derived from SAP Activate, manually defined project tasks and tasks generated from requirements

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/task-management

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/consuming-sap-activate-tasks

Use Project Tasks for work that is not a single object outcome:

  • migration tooling/setup (templates, connectivity, staging approach)
  • data governance, cleansing rules, naming conventions
  • cross-object cutover activities
  • runbook creation, hypercare checklist

Question 2. How to structure activities across target environments (D / Q / P)

Cloud ALM does not force a single right pattern but it does give you strong organizing points: phases/sprints/milestones (timeboxes), workstreams, tags, and a deployment plan/system landscape linkage

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/project-planning-timeboxes

https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-cloud-alm/implementation/sap-cloud-alm-implementation-expert-portal/project-management.html

A pattern that scales without exploding the backlog

Keep one User Story per migration object or object group and use:

  • Milestones for migration cycles (Mock 1, Mock 2, Dress Rehearsal, Cutover)
  • Tags or naming convention to mark environment D/Q/P
  • Sub-tasks for each environment only where it adds control

Example one object user story:
User Story: Business Partner migrated and reconciled
Sub-tasks (typical):

  • Mapping and transformation rules finalized (D)
  • Trial load + error remediation (D)
  • Mock Load #1 + reconciliation pack (Q)
  • Mock Load #2 / Dress rehearsal + timing evidence (Q)
  • Cutover load + reconciliation + business sign-off (P)

This keeps the object story stable, while execution iterates through environments and cycles

Use environment-separated groupings only if:

  • different teams own D vs Q vs P execution and
  • you need independent scheduling/ownership/visibility per environment

Question 3. Common templates / proven structuring approaches

Template A: Data domain -> objects -> cycles

  • Workstream: Data Migration and optionally sub-workstreams like Finance / Logistics / Sales
  • Requirement: Finance master data migrated
  • User Stories: G/L accounts, cost centers, profit centers, etc.
  • Milestones: Mock 1 / Mock 2 / Dress rehearsal / Cutover

Best when you have strong data domain ownership and want clear object accountability

Template B: Migration wave ->objects best for phased rollout / multiple countries

  • Requirement: Wave 1 data scope migrated (country/site/business unit scope)
  • User Stories: either (a) one per object in wave or (b) one per wave with object sub-tasks
  • Milestones: Wave go-live readiness gates, plus mock cycles inside the wave

Best when rollout governance is wave-driven

Template C: Cutover-cycle centric best when go-live risk is the driver

  • Create a Cutover-focused cluster of tasks in the Deploy phase:
    • final extraction
    • delta logic
    • production load steps
    • reconciliation & sign-off
    • go/no-go decision points
    • Cloud ALM‚Äôs timesbox concept (phases/milestones) supports exactly this style of cutover gating

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/project-planning-timeboxes

Summary:

  • SAP Cloud ALM Project Management capabilities overview workstreams, tags, timeboxes, deployment plan/system groups are explicitly called out
  • SAP Cloud ALM help topics around Tasks/Requirements/timeboxes tasks from SAP Activate, project tasks, requirement-generated tasks, phases/sprints/milestones

More details below:

https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-cloud-alm/implementation/sap-cloud-alm-implementation-expert-portal/project-management.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/task-management

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/project-planning-timeboxes

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/approving-requirements

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/consuming-sap-activate-tasks

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Learning SAP BTP with Terraform: What Should Come Next?
entry.content:
I‚Äôm relatively new to the SAP ecosystem. Recently, I started learning SAP BTP and paired it with Terraform to understand how modern SAP landscapes can be automated using Infrastructure as Code.

The journey wasn‚Äôt smooth. As a beginner in SAP, understanding how BTP accounts, subaccounts, entitlements, directories, and services fit together took time. Adding Terraform on top of that introduced a new set of challenges‚Äîprovider behavior, state management, and errors that weren‚Äôt always obvious from documentation.

Despite the ups and downs, this experience helped me build a solid foundation in both SAP BTP and Terraform. I now have a clearer understanding of how SAP BTP environments are structured and how they can be managed in a scalable, repeatable way.

Now I‚Äôm at a crossroads, and this is where I‚Äôd really like input from the community.

From a market and demand perspective, what should I focus on next?

  • Should I go deeper into SAP BTP services like CAP, Integration Suite, or Extension Suite?

  • Is there stronger demand for DevOps-style roles, focusing on CI/CD, automation, and governance in SAP BTP?

  • Would combining BTP + security, identity, and authorization be more valuable?

  • Or is expanding into multi-cloud Terraform and platform engineering the smarter move?

As someone early in the SAP journey, I want to invest time in skills that are not just interesting, but also relevant and in demand.

Looking forward to insights from people already working in the SAP BTP and cloud automation space.

entry.title: Re: Queries surrounding Form Language and Form Country/Re...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, billing output (Form Language and Form Country/Region) is determined exclusively by customer‚Äërelated business partners such as the Bill‚Äëto Party and Payer.

In the scenario where the Bill‚Äëto Party is in one and the employee processing is in another country, the system will generate the invoice according to Bill‚Äëto Party's country and language rules. The employee processing's country has no influence on billing output, as internal employee roles are not considered in Output Management determination. 

You can also refer to the following SAP‚Äëprovided documentation:

  • Output Management for Sales and Billing Documents
    SAP Help Portal
  • Manage Billing Documents ‚Äì App Documentation
    SAP Help Portal
  • Invoice Forms & Country‚ÄëSpecific Templates
    SAP Help Portal
  • Country/Region‚ÄëSpecific Functions
    SAP Help Portal
  • Form Language issues explained by SAP experts
    SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Add variant of main program to called program in a ba...
entry.content:
When the first executed program schedules the second program in a new background job, first create (or update) a variant with the same name as the one received but for the new program, and then explicitly call the second program with this variant.

  1. Retrieve the currently executed variant (SYST-SLSET).
  2. Create or update a new variant for the next program (using functions like RS_VARIANT_VALUE_SAVE or RS_CHANGE_CREATED_VARIANT).
  3. Create the new job by adding a step with the explicit variant name (using the JOB_SUBMIT function with the REPORT and VARIANT parameters, without using the SUBMIT statement).
  4. If the first background job ID (JOBCOUNT, JOBNAME) is passed to the second program, the second program can execute the BP_JOB_DELETE function to delete the previous job.

Question: Why was this call model used?

Risk: If many jobs are run with the same variant of the first program, the variant generated for the second program may be overwritten before execution...

entry.title: Connecting SAP S/4HANA On-Prem Directly to Advanced Event Mesh using Cloud Connector - finally!
entry.content:
With Package Integration 1.4.0 (December 2025), the Advanced Event Mesh Adapter for SAP Integration Suite delivers several noteworthy updates.

One of these has been requested repeatedly by customers, partners, and SAP architects working in hybrid landscapes:
official support for on-premise connectivity via the SAP Cloud Connector.

In addition to this key enhancement, the release also includes other technical changes, such as an update to the default acknowledgment mode.

What‚Äôs New in Package Integration 1.4.0?

1Ô∏è‚É£On-Premise Connectivity via SAP Cloud Connector

The AEM Adapter can now officially route traffic to on-premise systems through the SAP Cloud Connector.

This enables a supported hybrid architecture where:

S/4HANA on-prem produces events
SAP AEM distributes them
Network security remains intact

Important note from the official release notes:

Avoid mixing proxy configurations within the same tenant to prevent unexpected routing behavior.

This is especially critical in complex hybrid tenants.

2Ô∏è‚É£Change of Default Acknowledgment Mode

The default acknowledgment mode has changed from:
      Automatic Immediate
to  Automatic On Exchange Complete

Technical implications:

  • Clearer delivery semantics

  • improved error handling
  • Better alignment with enterprise-grade integration scenarios

Package Integration 1.4.0 introduces multiple technical improvements.
The Cloud Connector support for the Advanced Event Mesh Adapter is a long-requested and architecturally significant enhancement.

It enables a clean, supported reference architecture to connect SAP S/4HANA on-premise directly to SAP Advanced Event Mesh, using SAP Cloud Connector as the secure hybrid backbone.

For SAP architects, this removes a major blocker when designing modern, event-driven hybrid landscapes.

https://api.sap.com/package/AdvancedEventMeshAdapterforSAPIntegrationSuite/documents

entry.title: Product Compliance in SAP Cloud ERP 2602
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP's ready-to-run public cloud ERP software solution.  

 SAP Cloud ERP is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data, and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the cloud ERP ecosystem‚Äìcustomers, partners, and SAP experts.  

 

In this blog post I‚Äôd like to outline the innovations for SAP Cloud ERP 2602 Release in the area of Product Compliance. These are the topics that are covered:

Safety Data Sheet and Label Management

  • Extension of safety data sheet (SDS) generation (7DO)
  • SDS management and shipment with branded products with specific data for final SDS generation (3VR)
  • Definition of a fallback SDS for a product (3VQ)

 Dangerous Goods Management

  • Support for multi-component products that contain two or more dangerous goods (3FC)

 

In case you do not need all the information below and briefly want to get an overview of the release highlights, please watch this video with the top four key innovations:

Video#1: SAP Cloud ERP 2602 for Product Compliance

 

Extension of safety data sheet (SDS) generation



Business Background
To maintain compliance, it is crucial that Safety Data Sheets (SDS) reflect the latest regulatory requirements and clearly communicate any updates to recipients. This includes providing more granular information in specific sections, such as handling and storage, and highlighting changes between document versions for better transparency.

Key Features
This innovation improves the SDS generation process for regulatory assessments, incorporating updated requirements for Section 7 (Handling and Storage) and Section 15 (Regulatory Information). It is now possible to include vertical change marks in the final SDS, which visually indicate all data that has been modified since the last released version, ensuring changes are easily identifiable. Additionally, the GHS classification has been enhanced to allow for the maintenance of the index number and annex name, which will be included as output on the SDS.

 

 

Video#2: Demo Extension of safety data sheet (SDS) generation



SDS management and shipment with branded products with specific data for final SDS generation



Business Background
Companies often market the same base product under different brand names, each with unique compliance obligations for the specific markets in which they are sold. It is essential to manage market-specific data, such as Poison Centre Notification (PCN) details like the Unique Formula Identifier (UFI), and ensure this information is correctly represented on the SDS for that branded product.

Key Features
This innovation allows you to apply specific compliance purposes to branded products, determining which data is relevant for the markets where the product is sold. The system now supports compliance requirement versions for the Poison Centre Notification, enabling you to manage the registration status and UFI number for a branded product. When an SDS is generated and shipped, this UFI number is now automatically included on the final document.

 


Video#3: Demo SDS management and shipment with branded products with specific data for final SDS generation

 

Definition of a fallback SDS for a product



Business Background
In scenarios where a product is shipped to a country without a specific, locally compliant SDS being available, the shipment process could previously fail, causing delays. To prevent these interruptions, businesses need a contingency to provide a standard, alternative SDS, ensuring that at least some safety information is shared with the customer and the shipment can proceed.

Key Features
You can now define a global fallback SDS within the system by activating it for a specific compliance requirement, such as "German SDS in English." If the system does not find a released, country-specific SDS for a product during shipment, it automatically uses this predefined fallback document. This feature helps to minimize shipment errors and ensures that customers receive critical safety information, even if it is not in the 100% correct local format.

 


Video#4: Demo Definition of a fallback SDS for a product

 

Support for multi-component products that contain two or more dangerous goods



Business Background
Products that are sold as a single unit but consist of multiple components (e.g., a two-part glue kit) present a challenge for dangerous goods management. Classifying each component individually is often insufficient, as regulations may require classifying the entire kit as a single entity to ensure compliant handling, checks, and documentation throughout the logistics process.

Key Features
This feature integrates the processing of multi-component products directly into the existing dangerous goods framework, allowing for classification at the product header level. Users can now classify the entire multi-component product, define packaging details for the kit, and assign relevant enclosure variants for transport. This ensures that dangerous goods checks in sales and delivery processes are executed correctly on the main product, not the individual components.

 

 

Video#5: Support for multi-component products that contain two or more dangerous goods

 

Thanks for taking the time to read this blog.

Don‚Äôt hesitate to leave a comment and check out our community page to ask your questions and engage with the experts. Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts. 

 

More Information

For a more in-depth exploration, please note that the EHS & Product Compliance Infodays will be held in Amsterdam from March 24th to March 25th. You can view the agenda and register here.


Ô∏èWatch the replays of our SAP Cloud ERP 2602 Early Release Series! 

From January 12 to January 16, 2026, we hosted a series of 22 expert-led live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the 2602 release of SAP Cloud ERP. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand‚Äìanywhere, anytime. 

 

Find all our assets 

We at Cloud ERP Product Success offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you below:

entry.title: SAP GUI for Mac - unable to open files if file name contains spaces (test.pdf vs test 1.pdf)
entry.content:
Hi,

We have found a problem in our SAP environment that if file attached to document has (blank) spaces in file name, MacOs SAP GUI is not able to open that file.

File is being download, we can see it in download folder, but it not able to open it.

We have tested it by uploading 2 the same file with different names "1.pdf" and "2 test.pdf" and only 2nd file is not opening.

Windows SAP GUI doesn't have this issue, but Mac has. It think this is related to the way how path are handled on Mac (Unix)

In order to open path App need to use brackets or back slashes to indicate spaces in path

For example:

"/private/var/folders/gf/cf6hg_l55hg8d5prxtgqwxmh0000gq/T/tomaszjanicki/SAPGUI/2 test.docx"

or

/private/var/folders/gf/cf6hg_l55hg8d5prxtgqwxmh0000gq/T/tomaszjanicki/SAPGUI/2\ test.docx

 attached SS you can see 1 file open and 2nd fails with error.

Is this common problem on Mac? is there fix for this kind of issue?

entry.title: Driving adoption by structuring the current available content for SAP Contract and Lease Management
entry.content:
In an environment where organizations juggle complex supplier relationships, diverse lease portfolios, and evolving accounting standards, moving contract and lease management to the public cloud is no longer a nice-to-have‚Äîit is a strategic imperative. Cloud delivery accelerates time to value, embeds compliance such as IFRS 16 and ASC842 directly into daily operations, and seamlessly connects contract data with sourcing, procurement, finance, and asset management. SAP Contract and Lease Management, particularly within SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, supports both real estate leases‚Äîsuch as land and buildings‚Äîand non‚Äìreal estate leases, including car fleets, machinery, technical equipment, and other movable assets. By managing valuation, accounting, and postings for both portfolios in a single integrated solution, organizations achieve stronger governance, lower risk, and better, insight-driven decision-making across their entire lease landscape.

As SAP‚Äôs Contact and Lease Management is a core functionality that enables further possibilities, it makes sense to structure both the currently available content and future additions. As the topic and its content will continue to grow, I would like to introduce an organizational approach to cluster new content. This will help new joiners and beginners, as well as advanced users, to quickly understand which content areas will be covered going forward.

Further the content should be named with the following naming convention.

  • SAP Contract and Lease Management Process Details: Title
  • SAP Contract and Lease Management E2E: Title
  • SAP Contract and Lease Management Product & strategy updates: Title
  • SAP Contract and Lease Management Architecture: Title

 

 

I propose the following structure. The sections below explain when each category should be used.

  • Process Details
    Use this section when a blog explains specific steps or details of a process. This may include information about individual tiles or the handling of subprocesses.
  • Architecture
    Use this section for topics related to the architecture of Contract and Lease Management, including system design and integration aspects.
  • Product and strategy updates
    Use this section to share product-related information such as new features, release updates, or hotfixes provided by Product Management for Contract and Lease Management. This section also includes product strategy.
  • E2E
    This section offers a broader, end-to-end view of SAP Contract and Lease Management, focusing on overall concepts and best practices.

Below is a selected list of useful SAP blogs related to Contract and Lease Management.
This list is not exhaustive and can be expanded over time.

E2E

  1. The article is about how SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition handles lease accounting to comply with international standards like IFRS 16 and ASC 842.

Three main aspects of the blog:

  • It automates lessee and lessor accounting processes, including calculations for Right-of-Use assets, liabilities, and periodic postings.
  • The solution supports both IFRS 16 and ASC 842 standards, including exemptions for short-term and low-value leases.
  • It integrates with the Universal Journal for transparency and uses a clean-core approach to simplify compliance and audits.

Source: Cutting Through the Complexity: Lease Accounting i... - SAP Community

  1. The blog explains SAP Contract and Lease Management in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition and how it supports lease accounting under IFRS16 and other standards.

The three most important aspects, see below:

  • SAP Contract and Lease Management provides tools and best practices to manage lease-in, lease-out, and sublease contracts, including valuation and periodic postings for IFRS, US GAAP, and local GAAP.
  • It enables contract creation, mass migration, valuation, and adjustments through dedicated apps, ensuring compliance and automation of financial postings.
  • The solution integrates with Finance and Asset Accounting, offering reporting capabilities and a standardized approach for companies moving from custom systems to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.

Source: CLM in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - SAP Community

The difference between the two is as follows:
The first summary focuses on lease accounting functionality in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, explaining how the system automates lessee and lessor processes and supports IFRS 16 and ASC 842.
The second summary takes a broader process-oriented approach, covering contract creation, migration, valuation, and reporting.

Architecture

  1. The blog is about SAP‚Äôs approach to real estate management architecture and solution options within the SAP Intelligent Suite.

The three most important aspects, see below:

  • It explains key business capabilities like property, workspace, and occupancy management, along with compliance for financial leases under IFRS16.
  • The article compares solution options: SAP S/4HANA for Contract, Lease and Real Estate Management (RE-FX), SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition Contract and Lease Management, and the new Planon Real Estate Management partnership.
  • SAP Cloud for Real Estate is being phased out, and SAP Real Estate and Facilities Management by Planon is positioned as the future target architecture for comprehensive real estate management.

Explanation: SAP Real Estate and Facilities Management by Planon together with SAP Contract and Lease Management is SAPs ‚Äúgot-to‚Äù solution for commercial and corporate real estate business processes. Core functionality to support Real Estate and Facility Management requirements is in SAP Contract and Lease Management.

Source: Architecture Decisions for Real Estate Management - SAP Community

 

Release and strategy updates

  1. Release updates
    These are the latest releases updates for Finance. There is a chapter for Contract and Lease in each blog.
  • Finance with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - SAP Community
  • Finance with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 - SAP Community
  • Finance in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2408 - SAP Community

  1. Strategy updates

SAP is expanding its SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition portfolio through strategic partnerships, such as with Planon, to deliver integrated real estate and facility management solutions.

  • The collaboration enables seamless data flow between smart technologies and ERP processes, leveraging SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition for finance and Planon for real estate management, all based on a unified data model.

  • Future innovations and feature development will focus on SAP Contract and Lease Management integrated with Planon, while SAP RE-FX remains available for specific use cases but will not receive major new enhancements.

Source: Real Estate Management with SAP‚Äã and Planon - SAP Community


Strategy update January 2026, expanding strategic portfolio. Please find the most relevant points below.

  • SAP‚ÄìPlanon Strategic Solution Extension
    Planon‚Äôs Real Estate & Facilities Management solution has become an SAP Solution Extension (SolEx) as of January 2026. This reflects a deep strategic partnership, with SAP selling, supporting, and aligning the solution under its premium qualification framework.
    The combined solution merges: SAP Contract & Lease Management for finance, compliance, and lease processes Planon for operational real estate, space, workplace, maintenance, and sustainability. Together, they deliver a holistic, end to end RE/FM ecosystem across operational and financial processes.

  • Roadmap, Quality Assurance & Future Strategy
    SAP and Planon jointly manage roadmap alignment, support, integration, and lifecycle assurance to reduce upgrade risks.

    Future innovation focuses on the SAP & Planon solution as a solution extension, while legacy RE-FX remains supported but not extended ‚Äî except for residential RE in DE/AT/CH.

Source: SAP Real Estate and Facilities Management - SAP Community

Bringing more structure to the topic may help beginners but also advanced colleagues to find the related information.

This is the first blog in series which will be provided in a regular sequence.

The next blog will be about the latest release in SAP Contract and Lease Management including the upcoming new release 2602.

entry.title: Re: Need to know how can Return Revenue GL can be assigne...
entry.content:
Hello @abulhasnat 

Thank you for your question

Yes, you can achieve what you described in the public cloud‚Äôs standard behaviour but not by using ‚Äúreturn order type‚Äù directly.

In public cloud, Revenue Account Determination defines the revenue GL used in the credit memo billing document. The CBAR or CBRE document type is not a direct key, so you must separate the return posting by using something that ensures visibility to account determination. See https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition-sales-configuration/building-pricing-procedures-for-calculation-logic for more details.

A standard way I suggest enabling you get a different revenue GL only for returns credit memos is to use a return only pricing condition or a return only pricing procedure that posts with a different account key, then you map that account key to a different revenue GL in Automatic Account Determination. Account key is responsible for linking condition values to different GL accounts in FI. I therefore recommend on a high level to:

  1. Identify which pricing condition is currently posting your revenue on the credit memo
  2. Create a return specific condition type that you will only use for CBAR or CBRE related billing.
  3. Then assign a dedicated account key to that condition type in the pricing procedure.
  4. Finally, maintain account determination for that new account key so it points to your required return revenue GL. See KBA 3651280 for more details.

This should ensure your sales orders and standard credit memos keep using the existing account key and GL, while your returns credit memos use the new account key and differences GL.

Here is a guidance on how to approach it:

Step 1: In your tenant, open Display Billing Documents, open the credit memo created from your return process. Then choose More  ---> Environment --> Account Determination. Note the result of the account key and determination

Step 2: Is for you to maintain the different revenue GL for the return account key. For this open your CBC, then configuration and enter your workspace, choose configure your solution and search for Automatic Account Determination. Finally, maintain a new entry for your new account key and assign the target revenue GL. This is where you replicate VKOA style logic in public cloud.

Step 3: Is to for you to ensure only your returns use that account key. In CBC, in your Configure Your Solution, search for your pricing configuration activity and assign the new account key to the return specific condition type in your pricing procedure.

Her is a summary:

  • Standard solution is possible if you separate the return credit memo posting by using a different account key in pricing, then map it to a different revenue GL
  • You can use Display Billing Documents to validate the key you used through account determination simulation
  • If you cannot adjust account keys, use extensibility to determine account.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Release Highlights SAP Integrated Product Development Q1, 2026
entry.content:
New year, new features! Welcome to our blog series on the latest developments in the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release. This blog highlights four innovations in SAP Integrated Product Development, our ready-to-run Cloud PLM software solution..  We are starting the year strong, adding more cloud-native technologies that help you manage your business processes end-to-end, for innovation and sustainable products. 

In this blog post, I‚Äôd like to outline some of the latest features of SAP Integrated Product Development, from releases 2509 through 2602. These are the topics that are covered:

  • Defining documents for components of the product structure

  • Defining customer-specific properties for product structure instances

  • AI-assisted hotspot creation for visualization diagrams

  • Dynamic data visualization

In case you do not need all the details below and briefly want to get an overview of the release highlights, please watch this video to get a high-level glimpse on these innovations:

Video#1: Release Highlights SAP Integrated Product Development

What's New in Enterprise Product Structure?

Defining documents for components of the product structure

Business Background

Thanks to the integration of document management features into the product structure of SAP IPD, users can now work with documents with more ease, directly from their product structures. This new feature enables users to use a document as describing entity in the Enterprise Product Structure (EPS). ‚Äã They can link documents to a selected level of the product structure and access documents directly from the structure.

Key Features

Search for documents and link them to a selected level of the product structure. Control the validity of different documents, for example, by linking a specific document to a specific product series. Also, access existing documents directly from the Enterprise Product Structure.

 

Video#2: Defining documents for components of the product structure

 

Defining customer-specific properties for product structure instances

Business Background

This new feature enables customers to specify customer-specific instance properties with values and units of measure, increasing flexibility and supporting subsequent processes by defined properties and values on instances within product structures. Components automatically inherit the correct set of properties based on their assigned product category. This ensures consistent data, reduces manual setup, and makes it easy to standardize attributes across similar products.

Key Features

Specify product properties with values and units of measure, add map them to instances of the product structure. You can use this feature, for example, to map properties from CAD files via design items to products and product structures.

 

Video#3: Defining customer-specific properties for product structure instances

 

And what are new highlights of Visualization?

Now let‚Äôs have a look at our latest innovations for Visualization, including the following AI-powered feature:

AI-assisted hotspot creation

Business Background

You can now automatically generate hotspots from 2D drawings, including piping and instrumentation diagram (P&ID) symbols, and associate them with back-end business data. This significantly improves the efficiency of hotspot creation and business data mapping and helps to reduce human errors resulting from manual processes. Use this innovation to digitalize PDF drawings for asset management and streamline the digital transformation journey of legacy drawings.

Key Features

Use AI to automatically create hotspots from 2D drawings and associate them with back-end business data. The system uses a trained object detection model to recognize piping and instrumentation diagram (P&ID) symbols and automatically create hotspots for the detected symbols. Then, it lets you map the generated hotspots with the relevant business data. 

 

Video#4: AI-assisted hotspot creation

 

Dynamic data visualization

Business Background

This new feature enables you to remotely monitor key systems or operations (such as the production line or asset) in real time. Display real-time data (for example, sensor or IoT data) in visualizations to reflect live temperature, pressure, and so on. You can monitor changes to the data, spotting issues as they emerge and empowering them to react instantly to minimize downtime.  

Key Features

Visualize changes to key parameters in real time.  Administrators can create templates to determine the styling and color of the data to be displayed, and other details of the data mapping. Users can choose a styling, data mapping, and refresh time of the content based on such templates.

 

Video#5: Dynamic data visualization

 

Watch the replays of our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 Early Release Series! 

From January 12-16, 2026, we hosted a series of compelling live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You can find the recordings of your past sessions on SAP Learning. As a partner, you will find the recording and presentation for Manufacturing as well as other topics of interest via the Empowering SAP partners site.

Don‚Äôt hesitate to leave a comment and check out our community page on ERP or our community page on PLM to ask your questions and engage with the experts. Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts. 

Follow me on LinkedIn and stay up-to-date with our latest enablement assets: linkedin.com/in/annette-garcia-lorenzo

 Find all our assets  

The release 2602 showcases more 130 innovation highlights across the portfolio. Check out our release document for all the details!

We at Cloud ERP and SCM Product Success offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Click on the enablement wheel below and check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you:

entry.title: EWM - Replenishment Process
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I‚Äôm working on a scenario where we need to activate Planned and Automatic Replenishment for the BA.
One storage type will use fixed bins, and another will work with dynamic bins. Both storage types are already configured and behaving as expected.

The BA, however, has additional technical requirements:

1 ‚Äì Support both full-HU and partial-HU replenishment

The system must determine at runtime whether the destination should be replenished using:

  • a full HU (direct HU-to-bin movement), or
  • a partial HU (picking only the required quantity from a source HU).

Dynamic-bin specific behavior

For the dynamic-bin storage type:

  • If the destination bin is empty, the requirement is to reuse the source HU as the destination HU, meaning the HU should be transferred without repacking.
  • If the replenishment is partial, the system must create an intermediate HU to transport the extracted quantity to the destination HU (i.e., a repack / pick-HU creation during WT processing).

Question

Given this variability between full-HU and partial-HU replenishment:

  • Do I need to define a dedicated Warehouse Process Type (WPT) to manage both behaviors (full HU vs partial HU),
    or
  • Can the standard WPT 3010 handle these scenarios without additional custom WPTs?

For fixed-bin replenishment control, we are using /SCWM/BINMAT.
For the dynamic storage type, replenishment quantities will be controlled at product level.

Thanks for your support!

entry.title: Re: Add variant of main program to called program in a ba...
entry.content:
Answer to the 2 questions:

  1. The released API is either BP_JOB_DELETE or BAPI_XBP_JOB_DELETE (*).
    BUT if you want to have 2 jobs, why would you need to delete one? Not a good practice, keep things clear: the job was scheduled so don't delete it. Also, why do you need to submit a new job?
  2. The ABAP statement SUBMIT VIA JOB USING SELECTION-SET always creates a new variant with a system-generated number, which is the copy of the original variant merged with the parameters passed explicitly. If you want to use a given variant and you don't want a variant with a system-generated number, you must call the function JOB_SUBMIT instead of SUBMIT VIA JOB.

(*) Concerning XBP, as it works on top of XMI, you'll need to wrap the call of BAPI_XBP_JOB_DELETE between BAPI_XMI_LOGON (select the interface XBP, latest version 3.0 ) and BAPI_XMI_LOGOFF.

entry.title: Transportation Management - What's New in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602
entry.content:
We are happy to announce the innovations for Transportation Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602. The What's New Presentation provides an additional overview of all innovations.

The innovations are balanced across the areas core functions, user experience, extensibility and integration, thus providing value addition for the whole portfolio. As always, this release has been a great team effort, and I am more than happy to dive right into it.

CORE FUNCTIONS

Subcontracting Process with Transportation Management

With this release we enable the long awaited and heavily demanded subcontracting process (scope item BMY)  to work with Transportation Management in which you deliver raw materials/components to a subcontractor and in return receive the finished product. You can now plan the outbound transport and/or the inbound transport and the system makes sure that also the freight costs involved are properly distributed and allocated to the finished product. For the outbound transport you can additionally leverage Warehouse Management in Public Cloud to efficiently run your warehouse operations.

Figure 1: Subcontracting Process and involved outbound and inbound transports

Consignment Fill-Up and Pickup with Transportation Management

Similar to the subcontracting process, also the consignment fill-up and pickup process (scope item 1IU) is a widely used process that until now was not supported with Transportation Management. With this release we lifted this limitation and you can now plan the transport to fill-up the consignment stock at the customer as well as the pickup of any unused or no longer required consignment stock back to your on premise. For the outbound transport you can additionally leverage Warehouse Management in Public Cloud to efficiently run your warehouse operations.

Figure 2: Customer Consignment Process and involved outbound and inbound transports

Cross-company Purchasing Organizations

In the past you could only use purchasing organizations in freight orders and bookings that were uniquely assigned to a specific company code. If you have a central purchasing organization that procures transports for different company codes this leads to the creation of many artificial purchasing organizations, one for each company code.

Now you can use purchasing organizations that are not directly assigned to a company code. What remains however is, that the company code, for which this purchasing organization is procuring a concrete transport, must be uniquely specified on the freight order/booking to make sure that the freight costs are later allocated properly.

Figure 3: Cross Purchasing Organization can be used in Freight Documents

USER EXPERIENCE

Improve Loading Process with Cloud Transportation and Warehouse Management

This feature ensures consistent, simple and flexible loading process handling when using Transportation Management with WM by enabling customers to skip the loading step in the system before posting goods issue and checking out the freight order by automatically setting the respective status in the load and unload freight orders or with an RF device.

It eliminates unnecessary user interactions if recording the detailed loading/unloading activities are not important.

Figure 4: Loading Activities were automatically posted

EXTENSIBILITY

Print Form Extensibility for Dangerous Goods Print Forms

Until now it was not possible to extend the pre-delivered dangerous goods print forms and to customize its content. With this feature we provide completely reworked form data providers and extensible form templates that enable you to adapt the print forms to your very specific needs.

Local APIs for Freight Order/Booking improved

Local APIs are crucial to build extensions and custom apps and to complement the existing standard functionality. We invested significantly into Local APIs and provide now a set of operations for freight orders and bookings. More information is available on the API Hub.

Figure 5: Local APIs to extend business processes within SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

INTEGRATION

New Operations in OData APIs for Freight Order/Booking

Not only did we invest into local APIs to support extensibility within SAP S/HANA Public Cloud, but we also invested into the extension of our already existing OData (remote) APIs and added further operations. This enables you to build loosely coupled extensions on SAP BTP or in an own environment.

FIND OUT MORE!

An overview about the current and previous innovations for Transportation Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can be found in the List of "What's New" Presentations.

entry.title: SAP TM Report /SCMTMS/CHECK_ITEM_CONSISTENCY
entry.content:
SAP TM Report /SCMTMS/CHECK_ITEM_CONSISTENCY

Enhancement of SAP TM Item Consistency Check Report: Strengthening Data Integrity Through Advanced Validation

Introduction

The /SCMTMS/CHECK_ITEM_CONSISTENCY report serves as a critical data validation tool in SAP Transportation Management, ensuring the integrity of transportation-related items and business objects. As transportation operations become increasingly complex and data volumes grow, the need for comprehensive consistency checks has become paramount.

Current business challenges reveal significant gaps in item-level validation, particularly around duplicate ITEM_ID detection and automated correction capabilities. These inconsistencies can lead to planning errors, settlement discrepancies, and operational disruptions that impact the entire transportation process flow.

The enhancement initiative addresses these critical gaps by introducing advanced duplicate detection mechanisms and automated correction capabilities, transforming the report from a diagnostic tool into a comprehensive data quality management solution.

Current State Analysis

Existing Report Capabilities

The current /SCMTMS/CHECK_ITEM_CONSISTENCY report provides essential validation across TM item-level objects including freight units, transportation orders, and related documents. The report identifies missing or incorrect references between transportation items and their parent documents, detects orphaned data records lacking proper business object relationships, and verifies integrity of item-level master data assignments.

Key validation areas include:

  • Item-level object consistency across freight units and transportation orders
  • Parent-child relationship validation between items and documents
  • Status consistency checks between items and their business contexts
  • Quantity and business logic validations at the item level

Identified Gaps

Despite its comprehensive scope, the current implementation lacks critical validation capabilities:

Missing Duplicate ITEM_ID Detection: The report does not contain checks for duplicate ITEM_ID values within single freight documents, as confirmed by SAP Note 3055966. This gap can lead to processing errors and data integrity issues during transportation execution.

Limited Automated Correction: Current functionality focuses primarily on identification rather than resolution, requiring extensive manual intervention to address discovered inconsistencies.

Insufficient Hierarchy Validation: While basic item checks exist, comprehensive item hierarchy consistency validation requires enhancement, as addressed in SAP Note 2668639.

Enhancement Overview

Proposed Enhancements

  1. Duplicate ITEM_ID Detection

The enhancement introduces sophisticated duplicate detection logic that scans for identical ITEM_ID values within individual freight documents. The technical approach leverages optimized SQL queries with performance-conscious algorithms to identify duplicates without impacting system performance during large-scale validations.

Validation logic implementation includes:

  • Cross-table duplicate detection across TM item tables
  • Document-level grouping to ensure duplicates are identified within proper business contexts
  • Performance optimization through selective indexing and batch processing techniques
  1. Correction Report Introduction

A complementary correction report provides automated resolution capabilities for identified inconsistencies. The correction framework includes:

  • Automated Correction Capabilities: Pre-defined correction rules for common inconsistency patterns
  • Manual Correction Workflow: Guided correction processes for complex scenarios requiring business judgment
  • Rollback and Safety Mechanisms: Complete audit trails and rollback capabilities to ensure data safety during correction operations
  1. Extended Consistency Checks

Building on SAP Note 2668639, the enhancement extends validation coverage to include:

  • Item hierarchy consistency validation across multi-level transportation structures
  • Cross-reference validation between related TM objects
  • Enhanced data integrity checks covering previously unvalidated scenarios

Technical Implementation

Enhancement Framework

The implementation leverages SAP's enhancement framework through targeted modification of the existing report structure. Development approach utilizes implicit enhancement points within the report to maintain upgrade compatibility while extending functionality.

The correction report on architecture implements a three-tier approach:

  1. Detection Layer: Identifies inconsistencies using enhanced validation logic
  2. Analysis Layer: Categorizes inconsistencies and determines correction strategies
  3. Execution Layer: Applies corrections with comprehensive logging and rollback capabilities

Error handling mechanisms include transaction-safe processing, detailed error logging, and automatic rollback triggers for critical failures.

Key Features

Duplicate Detection Capabilities

Feature

Description

Benefit

Document-Level Scanning

Identify duplicate ITEM_IDs within individual freight documents

Prevents processing errors during transportation execution

Cross-Table Validation

Validates consistency across multiple TM item tables

Ensures comprehensive data integrity across the TM landscape

Performance Optimization

Batch processing with selective indexing

Maintains system performance during large-scale validations

Real-Time Alerts

Immediate notification of critical duplicates

Enables proactive issue resolution before business impact

Correction Mechanisms

Automated Correction Options: Pre-configured correction rules handle standard inconsistency patterns, including duplicate removal with business logic preservation, item hierarchy reconstruction, and reference relationship restoration.

Manual Review and Approval Process: Complex scenarios requiring business judgment are routed through structured approval workflows, ensuring business context is maintained during corrections.

Batch Processing Capabilities: Large-scale corrections can be processed in background jobs with comprehensive progress monitoring and error handling.

Implementation Guide

Prerequisites

System Requirements:

  • SAP TM 9.0 or higher with latest support packages
  • Sufficient system resources for batch processing operations
  • Database performance optimization for large item datasets

Authorization Requirements:

  • /SCMTMS/TOR and /SCMTMS/FU display and change authorizations
  • Background job scheduling permissions
  • Development and customization access for implementation

Development Steps

  1. Analysis and Design Phase: Comprehensive analysis of existing inconsistent patterns, design of correction algorithms, and definition of validation rules
  2. Code Development: Implementation of duplicate detection logic, correction report development, and integration with existing validation framework
  3. Testing and Validation: Unit testing of individual components, integration testing with existing TM processes, and performance validation with production-like data volumes
  4. Deployment and Go-Live: Phased rollout starting with development environment, comprehensive user training, and production deployment with monitoring

Configuration Requirements

Customization Settings: Configuration of correction rules, validation thresholds, and business-specific validation parameters through dedicated customization tables.

Parameter Configurations: System parameters for batch processing limits, performance optimization settings, and error handling thresholds.

User Role Assignments: Role-based access control for correction capabilities, approval workflows, and audit trail access.

Testing Strategy

Test Scenarios

Duplicate ITEM_ID Detection Testing: Comprehensive test scenarios covering single and multiple duplicate scenarios, edge cases with complex item hierarchies, and performance testing with large datasets.

Correction Functionality Validation: Testing of automated correction rules, manual correction workflows, and rollback mechanisms under various failure scenarios.

Performance and Volume Testing: Validation of system performance with production-scale data volumes, concurrent user scenarios, and batch processing optimization.

Benefits and Impact

Business Benefits

Improved Data Quality: Enhanced validation capabilities ensure higher data integrity across transportation processes, reducing downstream processing errors and improving operational reliability.

Reduced Manual Effort: Automated correction capabilities significantly reduce manual intervention requirements, freeing up resources for value-added activities.

Enhanced System Reliability: Comprehensive consistency checks improve overall system stability and reduce the risk of process failures during critical transportation operations.

Technical Benefits

Automated Inconsistency Resolution: Streamlined correction processes reduce the time required to resolve data quality issues from hours to minute.

Better Error Reporting: Enhanced logging and reporting capabilities provide detailed insights into data quality trends and correction effectiveness.

Streamlined Maintenance Processes: Integrated correction capabilities reduce the complexity of ongoing system maintenance and data quality management.

Best Practices

Development Guidelines

Coding Standards: Adherence to SAP development standards, comprehensive documentation, and modular design principles ensure maintainability and upgrade compatibility.

Performance Optimization: Implementation of efficient algorithms, selective data processing, and optimized database access patterns maintain system performance during validation operations.

Error Handling Best Practices: Comprehensive error handling, transaction safety, and detailed logging ensure robust operation under all conditions.

Operational Recommendations

Execution Frequency: Regular execution during maintenance windows, triggered validation after major data changes, and continuous monitoring for critical inconsistencies.

Monitoring and Alerting: Integration with system monitoring tools, automated alerting for critical issues, and dashboard reporting for data quality metrics.

Potential Challenges

Technical Challenges

Performance Impact on Large Datasets: Processing millions of transportation items requires careful optimization to avoid system performance degradation.

Complex Correction Scenarios: Some inconsistencies may require sophisticated business logic to resolve correctly without impacting ongoing operations.

Mitigation Strategies

Performance Optimization Techniques: Implementation of parallel processing, selective data loading, and optimized database queries ensure acceptable performance even with large datasets.

Phased Implementation Approach: Gradual rollout of correction capabilities allows fine-tuning and optimization based on real-world usage patterns.

Future Enhancements

Roadmap Considerations

Future development phases will include additional consistency checks for advanced TM scenarios, integration with other TM validation reports, and real-time validation capabilities during data entry processes.

Scalability Planning: Architecture designed to support increasing data volumes, multi-client environments, and cloud deployment scenarios ensures long-term viability.

Conclusion

The enhancement to the /SCMTMS/CHECK_ITEM_CONSISTENCY report represents a significant advancement in SAP TM data quality management. By introducing duplicate ITEM_ID detection and automated correction capabilities, organizations can achieve higher data integrity, reduce manual effort, and improve operational reliability.

The comprehensive approach addresses current gaps while providing a foundation for future enhancements, ensuring that transportation data quality management keeps pace with evolving business requirements. Implementation of these enhancements will transform the report from a diagnostic tool into a comprehensive data quality management solution, delivering measurable benefits in operational efficiency and system reliability.

Organizations planning to implement these enhancements should prioritize thorough testing, phased rollout, and comprehensive user training to maximize the benefits while minimizing implementation risks. The investment in enhanced data quality capabilities will pay dividends through improved operational efficiency and reduced maintenance overhead.

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM Introduces a "Feature Preview" Approach
entry.content:
SAP Cloud ALM is rolling out a new approach to feature releases. This approach provides users with an early look at what's coming. Currently, only some selected functional areas offer this preview window. The Preview window is approximately two weeks before features officially go live in the regular Wednesday feature delivery cycle.

The features will be marked as ‚ÄúPreview‚Äù in the SAP Cloud ALM What‚Äôs New page:

 

 

The goal is to provide this ‚ÄúPreview‚Äù information 2 weeks (one development sprint) before the feature is released. It can happen in some exceptional cases that the feature will be in ‚ÄúPreview‚Äù for 4 weeks or more.

 

## What This Means for Users

 

This preview approach provides customers with better visibility into upcoming functionality, : 

  • Plan for new capabilities ahead of time
  • Assess the potential impacts and benefits of new features on their existing processes.
  • Prepare training materials and documentation for better end-user adoption
  • Adjust workflows to incorporate new features

Partners can also leverage this information to prepare the adoption of these new features for their customers.

 

## Where to Find Previewed Features

 

All previewed features are accessible through the What's New Viewer on SAP Help Portal. You can check what's coming at: https://help.sap.com/whats-new/0cb91c1ef73b400f881823f8d5fd2dea

 

## Current Scope

 

It's worth noting that this preview capability isn't available across the entire SAP Cloud ALM platform yet‚Äîit's currently limited to . As this process matures, we expand it gradually to all SAP Cloud ALM functional areas.

 

This initiative reflects SAP's commitment to transparency and helping customers stay ahead of changes in their SAP Cloud ALM tenants. For teams managing complex SAP landscapes, having that extra two-week window can make a real difference in adoption and change management.

 Don‚Äôt hesitate to like this post if you think that this feature is useful for you.

entry.title: Re: entries of 2l and ol ledger difference
entry.content:
Hi @jerrysam ,

based on what you are writing, I would assume it is most probably a difference due to rounding differences. You said that you are doing an analysis on account level. In this case, multiple different materials might be the source for the difference. You can drill down further with the apps Material Inventory Values - Balance Summary and Material Inventory Values - Line Items to find the true source of the delta. The price unit should ideally be the same in different ledgers, especially if there is no good reason for it. This can easily lead to rounding differences in postings.

If you just want to see the same value in both ledgers, you can also manually adjust the material price to be identical which will also trigger a revaluation posting to correct the inventory value. This will of course not solve the root cause of any deltas. Please keep in mind that manual setting of the material price will overwrite any cost component split for the material.

I hope this help. I don't think I can really analyze it any better without access to the system. If you need further clarification for which you need someone looking at the system directly, you may also open a ticket.

Best regards
Marvin

entry.title: Re: How to use Custom Logic App to pass Contract Header d...
entry.content:
HI @bigflatfoot,

There is usually no process to update already created follow-up documents if the source document is changed.
I do see two potential workarounds:

1. Update via local event handler:
You could implement a local event handler for the I_SalesContract~changed event. In that implementation you could check for open sales orders with reference to the changed contract and update the order accordingly. One limitation here would be that it will not work if the order is currently locked by another user for example. You can find further details about local event consumption here.

2. Update via Custom Application job:
You could check regularly for updated Contracts an update the follow up sales orders. You can find further details about custom application jobs here. The limitation here is that it will not work immediately after the contract has been changed.

You could also think about a solution which combines the two approaches.

entry.title: HANA Cloud: Inconsistent Network Egress Consumption
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

First, here's some context: we're making use of BTP with the Cloud Foundry Runtime with AWS as our backing hyperscaler and our primary persistent is HANA Cloud.

For the problem: Towards the end of 2025, we noticed some peculiar behavior with regards to network egress in our HANA Cloud instance. We had a very stable level of network egress consumption between January and September 2025 but in October and November we saw this consumption nearly double before receding to more baseline levels in December. 

There are two problems with these changes in consumption levels:

  1. We had no discernable code changes that correlate to the increases beginning in October OR the decrease that began in December
  2. December is by far our highest volume month in terms of database use which is inconsistent with it returning to normal levels of network egress consumption

While this was initially discovered by looking at global account level consumption statistics, it was confirmed within the HANA Cloud dashboards themselves AND the metering and metrics APIs (as described here: Metering Metrics).

Our leading theory into why we see these random jumps is due to how Availability Zones (AZs) are handled within BTP. HANA Cloud instances very clearly have an AZ visible in HANA Cloud Central. In our particular case that zone is us-east-1b.

App instances are another case entirely though. SAP has published a note on the question (3476931 - Is it possible to get Availability Zone for BTP Cloud Foundry application?) which states the following as its resolution:

SAP controls the AZ of Cloud Foundry applications to ensure availability. It is not necessary/needed that customers know/manage the AZ for custom applications. 

This clearly indicates the actual AZ of app instances is out of control of customers. This reveals a potential problem though given that the underlying hyperscaler AWS charges for network traffic between distinct AZs in the same region. If we take these facts together:

  1. HANA Cloud is deployed in a particular AZ
  2. App instances are deployed in AZs under the control of SAP
  3. AWS charges for network data transfers across AZs

That would indicate that customers are open to seemingly random increases in network egress consumption based on how app instances are deployed and they have no means of controlling that. 

Now, there is a note (3443501 - HANA Cloud overage costs) that states managing network consumption is not SAP's responsibility, but given what we know about AZs, this seems customers lack the tools to adequately manage these costs.

The question: Given what we know, has anyone else experienced similar issues and how did you get this type of consumption under control? We really seem to be at a loss for this and these increase in consumption are non-trivial.

I appreciate any insights on the matter.

Thanks,

Brian

entry.title: How is the sales area determined on sales order inbound EDI processing
entry.content:
This blog aims to explain how the sales area is determined by the system during sales order creation when receiving it through EDI.

When the system cannot determine the sales area through any of the options, the error message "Sales area cannot be determined" can be found.

The following configuration activities are used to map business partners in supplier side and determine sales area/document type. They are essential for the system to be able to determine the sales area correctly.

  • Convert External to Internal Partner Numbers (101300)
  • Assign Customer/Supplier to Sales Organization Data (101337)

The sales order is determined by the system by following the bellow options:

1. Directly from the payload

If the sales area details are specified within the payload, then the system takes directly this sales area. Example in the payload:
<Order>
.........
       <SalesDocumentType>TA</SalesDocumentType>
       <SalesOrganization>1010</SalesOrganization>
       <OrganizationDivision>00</OrganizationDivision>
       <DistributionChannel>10</DistributionChannel>
........
</Order>

Receiving this payload, the system will determine the sales area 1010/00/10. If these fields are not present in the payload, then the system checks for the next option.

2. CPF framework determination

When a sales document is created or changed, the system can evaluate specific fields in the inbound EDI message to dynamically determine the sales area, sales document types, and discrepancy allowance for payment terms for the sales document to be updated or created. Configurable Parameters & Formulas (CPF) framework allow customers to dynamically define business rules to determine EDI required information based on data what is provided by buyer. 

For more information on how to use CPF flexible determination for sales area, follow the documentation bellow:

  • S/4HANA Q2C Sales Flexibility ‚Äì Determine Business Partner and Sales Area in B2B EDI Integration | SAP Community
  • Flexible Determination of Sales Area and Sales Document Types | SAP Help Portal

If the CPF formulas are not implemented, then the system will try to determine the sales area based on the next and last option.

3. Determined by the customer number

Using the following payload as an example:

<Party PartyType="SoldTo">
       <BuyerPartyID></BuyerPartyID>
</Party>
<Party PartyType="Supplier">
       <SupplierPartyID></SupplierPartyID>
       <BuyerPartyID></BuyerPartyID>
</Party>

The vendor number will be determined by following this priority:

  1. SupplierPartyID from "Supplier" Party
  2. BuyerPartyID from "Supplier" Party
  3. BuyerPartyID from "SoldTo" Party

After fetching this vendor number, the system will look for this vendor number in the configuration activity 'Assign Customer/Supplier to Sales Organization Data' (101337) and will fetch the sales area maintained there.
Note: this configuration activity is editable in all systems, this means it's not transportable, so you need to maintain it in every relevant system.

Summary

The system provides different ways of determining the sales area: directly (from the payload), flexibly (CPF) or indirectly (vendor number). If the system cannot determine the sales area through these 3 ways, the error "Sales area cannot be determined" is thrown. Then, you must revisit you configurations and payload to check if you're providing at least one of the options for the system to determine the sales area correctly.
